measured_by: percentage of selected investigations that were incriminating from a 20-item investigation list
justification: "Of the selected investigations, 45% was incriminating … whereas this percentage was 57 …" – the study treats the proportion of incriminating choices from the investigation list as the operational index of confirmation bias.
construct: Confirmation bias / preference for guilt-confirming information

measured_by: 0–100 rating scale where 0 =incriminating and 100 = exonerating for each investigation topic
justification: Pilot Study instruction: “Participants rated every investigation on a scale from 0 (incriminating) through 100 (exonerating).”
construct: Perceived direction of an investigation (incriminating vs exonerating)

measured_by: 0–100 importance rating scale for each investigation topic
justification: Second pilot study: “Participants rated the 20 investigations on a scale from 0 (not at all important) through 100 (very important).”

measured_by: binary choice to circle ‘innocent’ or ‘guilty’ after reading the case file
justification: “After having studied the case file, participants were given the following written instruction: ‘Now that you have read the case file, you must decide whether the suspect is innocent or guilty. Do so by circling the word "innocent" or "guilty" below’."

measured_by: number of additional investigations selected from the 20-item list
justification: “Participants … selected on average 5.4 additional investigations … whereas those in the latter group selected 4.6 investigations.”

measured_by: verdict choice to ‘convict’ or ‘acquit’ after reviewing evidence (with or without additional investigation results)
justification: “After obtaining the outcomes … participants were asked to indicate whether they would convict or acquit the suspect.”
